Description.val:
Procurement of Valve Regulated Lead Acid (VRLA) batteries and installation of Ship Alteration (ShipAlt) to modify submarines from use of legacy flooded battery (no longer in production at former sole source manufacturer) to new design VRLA battery.  Installation of the VRLA battery includes installation of a new Automatic Battery Monitoring system (ABMS) as part of the ShipAlt.  This program procures and installs initial and replacement VRLA batteries for all classes of submarines (LOS ANGELES, SEAWOLF , OHIO SSBN/SSGNs  and VIRGINIA) .  Batteries have a finite life and are consumables; this budget procures replacement VRLA batteries throughout the submarine service life on a notional 5 year replacement cycle.  

Battery operation and capacity is critical.  Without acceptable battery capacity submarines cannot deploy effectively reducing the submarine force at a time when Strategic requirements, force protection and intelligence gathering capabilities are in high demand by combatant commanders.  Beginning in FY19, program requirements were increased to provide needed critical support to operational submarines.  These are funded via HM830 and include:

Battery Installation Test Equipment/Fixtures: Procures battery charging and test equipment to support the testing, balancing, and charging of Submarine Batteries at Puget Sound Naval Shipyard (PSNS).  This replaces the current PSNS Battery Shop 1,500 AMP Motor Generator with a 5,000 AMP solid state battery charger and other improvements required to conduct pre installation battery testing and troubleshooting prior to installation on SSBN/SSGNs. 

Submarine Battery Evaluation Center (SUBBEC): Procures needed equipment and test stands for a full battery test station at NSWC Crane to test a full submarine battery (250+ cells).  This is vitally needed to help solve the battery life issues being experienced in the fleet.  The proposed system would allow 24/7 unmanned testing and evaluation within the existing submarine battery test activity at NSWC Crane.  Current capability must be constantly manned and monitored and only allows for testing of a small quantity of cells which does not provide a completely accurate representation of submarine battery operating profile or battery reaction to changes in profiles due to inherent in-balance in the strings of cells as installed on a submarine.

Automated Battery Monitoring System (ABMS) Tech Refresh: Upgrades the currently fielded ABMS system that was developed in 2002 and is suffering from continued obsolescence issues which are directly impacting the fleet operations.  Upgrades will be performed by NSWC Crane Power and Energy Division.  The Power and Energy Division has one of the only DoD owned and operated circuit board production lines with reverse engineering and technical capabilities required to perform this Tech Refresh.

HM002 LOS ANGELES SSN, HM008 OHIO Class SSBN/SSGN, HM009 SEAWOLF Class SSN, and HM010 VIRGINIA Class SSN:  Procures replacement low maintenance sealed lead acid batteries for all submarines.  This replaces flooded battery technology for which the industrial base ceased manufacture and support of in 2005.  OHIO Class SSBN/SSGN replacements include handling and shipping trays to speed change-out during short refit periods Funds are provided based on a 5 year planned replacement cycle. 

HM830 Production Engineering:  Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC) Crane, as the designated procurement activity and In-Service Engineering Agent (ISEA) monitors battery performance and schedules replacements with the fleet.  NSWC Crane is tasked with leading a Government & Industry Root Cause Analysis (RCA) team to identify and address battery performance issues and provide corrective actions to operational submarines. NSWC Crane conducts qualification testing of delivered VRLA and analysis of poor performing VRLA cells returned from operational submarines which has proven very beneficial to the Navy in detecting battery deficiencies before installation, thus alleviating critical emergent fleet impact and assisting in identifying failure modes to improve long term performance.  Funding provided to Puget Sound and Portsmouth Naval Shipyards include responsibilities for the VRLA and flooded battery inventory management, maintenance and storage, SHIPALT support, and AIT management. Also, Planning Yard and Lead Yard Services are funded through this line.

HM5IN Procurement for Install/Installation under $10M:  Procurement of Valve Regulated Lead Acid (VRLA) batteries and install of ShipAlt to modify submarines from use of legacy flooded batteries for the LOS ANGELES, OHIO, SEAWOLF and VIRGINIA Class Submarines.   Installation unit costs vary due to the availability types, location of installation and submarine type.  All initial procurements and installations for the OHIO and SEAWOLF Class are complete.  Funds remain for two initial procurements and installations, one for a VIRGINIA Class SSN planned for completion in FY18, and the final LOS ANGELES Class SSN in FY20.

Justification.val:
The FY 2019 funding request was reduced by $0.080 million to reflect the Department of Navy's effort to support the Office of Management and Budget directed reforms for Efficiency and Effectiveness that include a lean, accountable, more efficient government.

The increased funding for FY 2019 provides for 3 additional Main Storage Batteries (over last years levels) a series of critical three year projects for Submarine Battery program that includes the Battery Installation Test Equipment/Fixtures, the Submarine Battery Evaluation Center and the Automated Battery Monitoring System.  Details on these projects are included in the description above.

FY17 decrease is due to a Congressional Mark against the OHIO class main storage battery for being "previously funded".

Name.val: 1) HM002 - LOS ANGELES Class Main Storage Battery

Name.@footnote: 1.1  The current VRLA battery unit costs, depicted on the P40A exhibit, reflect the costs in the existing commercial vendor contracts and associated installation which varies based on hull type and availability type.
1.2 FY19 Material funds identified are for ancillary material required to set up for and support installations.

Name.val: 2) HM008 - OHIO Class Main Storage Battery

Name.@footnote: 2.1  The current VRLA battery unit costs, depicted on the P40A exhibit, reflect the costs in the existing commercial vendor contracts and associated installation which varies based on hull type and availability type.  FY19, FY22 & FY23 includes associated battery shipping tray.

Name.val: 3) HM009 - SEAWOLF Class Main Storage Battery

Name.@footnote: 3.1  The current VRLA battery unit costs, depicted on the P40A exhibit, reflect the costs in the existing commercial vendor contracts and associated installation which varies based on hull type and availability type.

Name.val: 4) HM010 - VIRGINIA Class Main Storage Battery

Name.@footnote: 4.1  The current VRLA battery unit costs, depicted on the P40A exhibit, reflect the costs in the existing commercial vendor contracts and associated installation which varies based on hull type and availability type.  FY19 & FY21 includes the associated battery shipping tray.

Name.val: 5) HM830 - Production Engineering / Test Equipment/ SUBEC / ABMS Tech Refresh

Name.@footnote: 5.2 Battery Installation Test Equipment/Fixtures FY19 new start.  Funding is provided for the purchase of battery charging equipment to support the testing, balancing, and charging of Submarine Batteries.  For this equipment will replace the Puget Sound NSY Battery Shop 1500 AMP Motor Generator with 5,000A AMP solid state battery charger in to Bldg. 978. Improvements are required to conduct pre installation battery testing and troubleshooting.

5.3 Submarine Battery Evaluation Center (SUBBEC) FY19 new start funding is provided for the full string battery test station (SUBBEC).  The Submarine Battery Evaluation Center tests multiple battery string configurations which mirror specific submarine class installations.  FY19 - FY21 funding encompasses the design phase, material procurement, performance evaluation, lab upgrades, installation and testing.

5.4 FY19 new start provides funding for ABMS Tech Refresh that will be performed by NSWC Crane Power and Energy Division.  The current plan is for material and Installation of the tech refresh beginning in Aug 2019.  The installation is on ABMS on all Class VRLA Battery modified submarines and will continue through FY21.

Name.val: 6) HM5IN Procurement for Install / Installation under $10M

Name.@footnote: Funds procure one Los Angeles Class battery in FY19 and installs it in FY20.
